To prepare one participant to play Anna. There are no lines to learn.- To be aware of the evidence-based guidelines that should be used in the management of newborn problems.

Pregnancy, Childbirth, Postpartum and Newborn Care (PCPNC) is a comprehensive guide for the care of mothers and newborn babies during pregnancy, childbirth and postpartum periods. This guide is designed to help mothers, babies, and their caregivers understand the basic principles of PCPNC and how they can use them in their daily work. The guide provides information on:- 1. What is the purpose of the Guide? 2. What does the Guide do? 3. Why is it important? 4.Essential NewbornCare Course### SHOW Read aloud slide/overhead 1/3 – What's the guide?- It helps with:- The collection, analysis, and timely treatment of complications!

This can be achieved by:- Encouraging the mother to be mobile during labor and to lay flat on her back when she gives birth.- Remember these basic needs of the baby at the time of birth and for the first few weeks of life.- We want the mother alert to her baby's needs.■ Write each point on the board as follows. 20 minutes to prepare the mother for the delivery.- Prepare the baby for the birth.- Make sure that the mother is comfortable in the position she is in.- Keep the baby in her arms and legs.- Take care of the newborn.- Do not let the baby lie down on her back.- Don't let the mother get too close to the baby.#### USE PCPNC- Participants to turn to Section D Childbirth: Labour, delivery and immediate postpartum care.- Allow the mother to lay on her side.- Carrying the mother upright as much as possible.

10-15 minutes after the birth of the baby, the mother and the child are in the same room. The mother is sitting on the side of the bed with the baby in her arms. When the baby is in the arms of the mother, the baby's hands are wrapped around her neck. The baby is being cared for by the mother. the placenta has been delivered to the mother, it should be given to the baby as soon as possible. If the baby is not able to breathe normally after delivery, it may be necessary for the mother to take a breathing exercise to help the baby breathe properly. This can be done by holding the baby in a position that is comfortable for him/her to do so. If he/she does not feel comfortable with his/her breathing movements, you may need to give him or her some pain relievers. 3. Care of the baby at the time of delivery## Session 2- Make these points- To "breathe normally" between the mother's breasts where it is easy for breastfeeding to start.

the baby's breathing is normal, it will rise and fall equally at around 30 to 60 times a minute. If the baby is not breathing normally both sides of its chest, it should be assessed at about 10 minutes after delivery. The higher the Apgar score, the better the condition of the baby. If a baby is breathing regularly, he should be evaluated at 15 minutes after birth. If he is drying, the breathing rate should be measured at 20 minutes. 3/10 – Eye care at the time of birth.- The mother and baby should stay in the delivery room for 15 minutes.- One drop of the solution or a small amount of ointment should be put on the inside of the baby's lower eyelid.- D12 and D19 Participants to turn to these pages.### Monitoring the baby Make these points available to the mother and the baby from the time the baby is born until after delivery of the placenta.- Each eye should be wiped with a separate dry clean cloth or two different clean corners of the towel.(until around 1 hour after birth) SHOW slide/overhead

- Keep breastfeeding initiated for at least 30 minutes after delivery. 2/11- The mother should be able to breathe through her mouth. 3/12- Breastfeeding should not be interrupted until the baby is ready to feed. 4/13- Initiation of breast feeding should be done as soon as possible after birth. 5/14#### USE PCPNC Participants to turn to D19.### Skin-to-skin contact and breastfed by the mother during the first hour of birth.### SHOW slide/overhead

the first breastfeeding of a newborn baby, make sure that the mother's breasts are not too close to the breasts of the baby.- When the baby is ready to breastfeed, the mother should be able to reach the breast by her/himself.- If the baby does not want to feed, it is best to give him/her the second breast. 25 M1 S3 Session 2 Care of the newborn child at the time of birth:- Make sure the mother and the baby are comfortable with each other.- Give the baby the right position to feed.######## SHOW slide/overhead 3/10 – A baby's first breastfed should be between her/his breasts during skin-toskin contact.

the first breastfeeding of a newborn baby, it is important that the mother and the baby are in the same position for at least 80 minutes before the baby starts feeding.- The mother should be able to feed the baby from both breasts as long as she is comfortable. If the mother is in a semi-sitting position the baby will find it easier to attach to the breast without help. However, if she is sitting or lying down, it may take up to 90 minutes for the baby to get comfortable with her position. Discuss participants' comments.#### Ask- The baby should not have any other foods or drinks apart from colostrum.- This baby is breastfed 50 minutes after delivery.- It contains many common diseases and contains many important growth factors and the brain and the nerves and the eyes.

2015-03-27T16:48:00+00,000 19:59:11+01:0.001 10:50:12+02:0% 11:58:13+03:0 % 12:57:14+04:0 °C 0 °F 1 °C -1 °F -2°F -3°F –4°F 0°F-5°F###### Session 2 SHOW slide/overhead 3/15 – Breastfeeding at the time of birth can be done with a baby in skin-to-skin contact unless the mother needs treatment requiring sedation.

15-20 minutes after delivery, the mother should be given a pre-lacteal feeding. If the mother is not able to express herself during the first 20-30 minutes of birth, the baby should be treated as if she were born by caesarean section. In this case, the breastfeeding should be stopped immediately and the child should be taken to the neonatal unit. The mother should not be forced to breastfeed for more than 30-40 minutes before the baby is ready to be fed.####### Make these points:- Caesarean section, instrumental delivery and breech delivery all carry increased risks to the mother and the baby.-! USE PCPNC Participants to make these points under the fourth point "There is NO NEED to put the baby into a Neonatal Unit.

the first hour(s) after delivery, the mother and the baby should be separated from each other. If the mother is uncomfortable with the positioning of her baby, she may need to be moved to another room. If she is comfortable with her positioning, she should be allowed to stay in the same room with her baby for at least 15 minutes. If it is not comfortable, then the mother should be taken to the neonatal unit where she will be given an epidural anaesthetic. If this is not possible, the child should be placed in a bed.#### USE PCPNC Participants to turn to K9.■ Ask What should we do if mother and baby separation is necessary until skin-to-skin contact can begin?- Wrap the baby in a clean dry warm cloth and place in a cot. Cover with a blanket. Use a radiant heater if the room is not warm or the baby is small.

baby's body temperature is below 37.4°C, he will need to be referred to another health facility.2- A baby who has a mild hypothermia (35–36°C) should be kept in skin-to-skin contact with the mother (or another person accompanying the baby) or should be wrapped in a cloth that has been pre-warmed to approximately 38°C.3- If the baby has mild hypotermia, the baby should be treated with antipyretics.4- If a baby has cold feet, it is necessary for the baby to be "rewarmed".5- The baby should not be left alone.6- A newborn baby needs to be kept warm.7- Newborn babies cool down much faster than adults because he cannot maintain a stable body temperature as easily.- The smaller the baby and the more premature the more difficulty he has in maintaining its temperature.

2009-2010, the Ministry of Social Affairs and Employment was responsible for the implementation of the Environment and Health Strategy, which was adopted in 1997.- The Environmental Health and Chemical Safety Unit (EHCSU) was established in the context of the National Health Plan (NHP).- The Environment and health impact assessment (EHIA) is an integral part of the national health policy, but it is not fully implemented in Estonia.- There is a lack of coordination between the environmental and health policies of the different sectors.- ####**Conclusions** **Executive summary: main conclusions and recommendations**- **Conclusions**- Environmental and health has further officially been recognised within the public health sector through the establishment of the EnvironmentalHealth and ChemicalSafety Unit within the Public Health Department of the ministry of social affairs.

the Ministry of Social Affairs is responsible for the implementation of the National Health Plan 2009–2020, there is a lack of information on environmental and health risk assessments in the public health sector.- The Ministry of Health and Social Affairs should be empowered to carry out a comprehensive evaluation of the environmental impact assessment processes in the national health system.- There is a need to improve the quality of the environment and health assessment procedures.- It is necessary to establish a coordination mechanism between the various stakeholders involved in the process- The Environmental Health and Chemical Safety Unit within the Department of Public Health should be strengthened with additional human resources to cover all relevant environment and healthy issues.- **Recommendations**- The Environment and Health and chemical safety unit within the Public Health Department of the Minister of Social affairs should be reinforced with more clear institutional leadership (specific ministry)- Toxicological training and risk a assessment requirements should be further strengthened.

health impact assessments should be carried out in accordance with the requirements of the Tallinn Charter: Health Systems for Health and Wealth adopted in June 2008. This report provides an interdisciplinary analysis of the environment and health system in Estonia. The main objectives of the report are as follows:- Improving the quality of health services in the health sector;- Increasing the level of transparency and accountability in health systems;- Enhancing the effectiveness of the health system;- Strengthening the role of health professionals in health protection;- Toxicological training and risk assessment needs to be strengthened.- Local authorities should be provided additional human and financial resources to undertake health risk and health assessment.- Education in environment and healthy issues, promotion of research and development in environmental and health issues should be enhanced.

the report, Estonia's environment and health system has been undergoing significant changes since 1990. In 2008, the Ministry of Health and Social Affairs launched the National Health Plan for the period from 1 January to 31 December, which is based on the European Union (EU) Directive 92/43/EEC on the protection of the environment from pollution, which was adopted by the European Parliament and the Council on 16 December 1799. The report also highlights the importance of environmental and health issues in the health system of Estonia.The report shows that the Environment and Health System of Estonia has clearly recognized the role of health promotion and disease prevention as an integral part of and as an addition to traditional health care services. Furthermore, the holistic approach to people and population health has become increasingly applied in everyday practice, but the performance needs to be measured to ensure continuous improvement.

of environmental and health risks in Estonia is not well understood, and there is a lack of institutional recognition of the importance of environment and health. Therefore, it is necessary to establish an institutional framework for the management of chemical safety and health in Estonia. In 2008, the Ministry of Social Affairs established the Department of Environmental Health and Chemical Safety, which has been responsible for the coordination of the work of the Environment and Health Department and the Chemical Safety Unit. However, since 1997, the Department has been under the responsibility of the Public Health Department.At least two people have been focused on environment and santé for a decade. Nevertheless, it has gained too little attention for a long time. In general, the review has shown that the main problem raised during the review was the following:Apart from specific environmental health hazards, concerns focus on structural aspects.

, the Ministry of Social Affairs is responsible for the implementation of the National Strategy for the Prevention of Cardiovascular Diseases 2005–2015, which covers the prevention of cardiovascular diseases in the health care sector. In addition, the Department of Health and Social Affairs has been tasked with the preparation of a national strategy on environmental and health risks and determinants, which will be implemented within the framework of the new National Health Plan (2020-2030) and the National Strategic Plan on Environmental and Health Risks and Determinants for the Health Care Sector, which was adopted by the Council of Ministers on 16 December 24, 25 and 26 November 29, 30 November and 1 December 31 December. The goal of this strategy is to improve the quality of health care in the public health sector and to reduce the number of deaths and injuries caused by chemical hazards.In addition, existing institutions with well-developed experience are required to comment on and review all legislation prepared by other sectors. However, this task is a positive achievement, and in future the Unit will focus on chemical safety and environment and health topics. The Head of the Environmental Health and Chemical Safety Unit supervises the work of the chief specialists.

of environmental and health information in the public health sector is not sufficient. In addition, there is a lack of a comprehensive overview and approach from an environment and health perspective. Furthermore, the National Health Plan 2009–2020 contains a chapter focusing on the need for strengthening the integrated activities related to environment and healthy conditions in the society. Although many data have been collected and processed from a health or an environmental perspective, the knowledge of and the methods used for health impact assessment needs to be further developed and implemented in the national and subregional level.Compared to the Environmental Strategy of 1997, the new Environmental Stratege 2300 adopted in 2400Estonia has made an important achievement is the compilation and provision of information on the environment and human health related to environmental factors. The third strategy currently under development is the Injury Prevention Strategy.

of health impact assessments in Estonia are based on the principle of intersectoral cooperation. In this context, the Ministry of Social Affairs and its Department of Public Health have been involved in the preparation of the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) reports for the 2008-2010 financial period. The EIA reports have been prepared in cooperation with the European Environment Agency (EEA), the European Commission (EC) and the European Parliament (EP). There is a need to improve the intersector cooperation in the field of environmental health and chemical safety.Estonia has made significant progress in environment and health policy-making. Indeed, interstoriality is an institutionalized process in developing national legislation and regulations. Many working groups have been established to improve and enhance cooperation between other sectors rather than taking into account health arguments in their decision-making processes and actions.

of the European Environment and Health Programme (ENHIS) was established in 1993 by the Ministers of Health of the Member States of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) to monitor and evaluate the implementation of the Environmental Performance Reports (EHPRs) of the OECD Member States. The objectives of the ENHIS are to: *(1)* improve the quality of life and health of children and adolescents; *(2)* increase the awareness of the impact of environmental factors on children's health and development, and *(3)*The ENHISs are based on the programme of environmental performance reviews launched by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) in 2003 to help ensure their individual and collective performance in environment and health services.

priority goal 1: prevent and significantly reduce the morbidity and mortality arising from gastrointestinal disorders and other health effects, by ensuring that adequate measures are taken to improve access to safe and affordable water and adequate sanitation for all children; and 2: reduce the risk of disease and disability due to hazardous chemicals and injuries, by promoting safe, secure and supportive human settlements for all kids.The European Environment and Health Policy Framework (EHPR) is a framework for the implementation of European environment and health policies.• regional priority target 3: reduce and substantially reduce the health consequences from accidents and wounds due to outdoor and indoor air pollution, thereby contributing to the reduction in the frequency of asthmatic attacks.The EHPRs in the case of ENHIS, focus on the risk factors that most affect the health of European children.

The National Health Plan 2009–2020, which was approved by the Estonian Parliament on 18 June 25, 26 and 27 June, provides a comprehensive framework for the development of the health care system in Estonia. The plan is based on the principles of public-private partnership (PPP) and the principle of mutual benefit. It aims to improve the quality of health care services provided by the public sector and to increase the level of participation of the private sector in the provision of health services to the public.Estonia's healthcare system is mainly publicly funded through solidarity-based mandatory health insurance contributions in the form of an earmarked social payroll tax, which amounts to about two thirds of total health care expenditure. The Ministry of Social Affairs is responsible for funding emergency care for uninsured people, ambulance services and public health programs. The role of the local municipalities in health care funding is relatively small and yet diverse.

s. This system was introduced in 2006 and is based on the principles of mutual recognition and mutual advantage. The financial incentives are designed to support the implementation of clinical and practice guidelines. In primary health care, an additional voluntary quality-based bonus system has been introduced since 1998 to provide financial incentive for monitoring and providing services to specialty nurses. In addition, this system provides incentives for the provision of high-quality services to specialist nurses and physicians. The main objectives of this system are to improve the quality of health care services provided by the health care providers and to increase the level of professionalism of the healthcare providers. As a result, the current health care system is built around countrywide primary care that builds on family doctors and nurses, managing chronic conditions and other age groups (such as children).

of the public health system in Estonia is based on the following principles: 1. Public health services are provided by the public authorities. 2. 2004, the National Environment and Health Action Plan (NEHAP) was approved by the Estonian Parliament. The NEHAP has been implemented in Estonia since 1997. In addition, the NEHAP provides a framework for the implementation of the European Union's Environmental Action Programme (EEAP), which was adopted by the Council of Europe on 18 December 25, 26 and 27 November 23.##The NEHAP was the first in Estonia to summarize the environmental risk factors to health. The actions formulated were based on an assessment of the population's exposure to hazardous environmental factors and on an evaluation of environment and health risk and setting priorities for action. The work group recommended that:## Economics and funding## Policy and strategies designed to address environment and healthy conditions should always be supported by appropriate resources and institutional framework.

economics and funding in the environment and health sectors of Estonia are not well understood. There is a lack of financial support for environmental and health policies in Estonia. This is due to the fact that these policies are not implemented by the government, but by NGOs and private sectors. In addition, there is an insufficient amount of public funding for environmental policies. For example, the Ministry of Social Affairs does not provide sufficient funding to fund environmental activities, but it does provide funding through grants and grants from the European Union and other international organizations.Financial funds for disease prevention activities and programmes are particularly rare. Many different sources of funding are available for environmental activities and programs in Estonia, but this is not the case in the transport sector.Thelack of funds is one of the biggest challenges and difficulties in the environmental sector. The State funds for health and health conditions are especially rare.

The amendments to the Environmental Impact Assessment and Environmental Management System Act *(97)*, which were introduced in 1998, are intended to ensure that environmental impact assessments are carried out in accordance with the provisions of the legislation on the protection of the environment and the health of human beings. In addition, the amendment provides for the introduction of a preliminary assessment procedure for the purpose of assessing whether the proposed activity is likely to result in significant effects on the environment.##- The educational curricula of the health sector need to be changed to integrate environment and health modules and to improve the quantity and the quality of the trained environmental and health professionals.

environmental impact assessment is conducted in accordance with the provisions of the Environmental Impact Assessment Act, 1990, which provides for the establishment of a national environmental assessment system. The assessment must be carried out by a competent body, such as the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, Fisheries, Water Resources and Climate Change, or by an independent entity such as an NGO or a non-governmental organization (NGO).The assessment shall be conducted under the authority of the Minister of the Environment, who shall be appointed by the President of the Republic.The environmental effects resulting from the implementation of a strategic planning document and the area likely to be affected must be taken into account based on the risks to human health and well-being, the environment, the cultural heritage or property.*(97)*Environmental impact assesment reports determine the potential environmental effects of the proposed activity and its actual alternatives, including the indirect impact and combined effects on the health, wellbeing and property of people, plants, animals, soil, landscape and protected natural objects. *(98)*

the environmental impact assessment process. In 2006, the Ministry of the Environment issued a report on the implementation of the health risk assessment in Estonia. The report found that there was a lack of knowledge and understanding of the requirements for including health in environmental impacts assessments, and that there were some problems with the inclusion of health risks in the assessment procedures. The results of the survey showed that there is a wide range of concerns regarding the quality of health impact advisory services provided by the local governments, as well as the need to re-evaluating the environmental effect assessment.In conclusion, the legislation needs to be changed to strengthen the responsibility of including health within environmental impactassessment. Châtelaine, Secretariat for the Rotterdam Convention, Tallinn, National Audit Office of Estonia, [web site]. http://ec.europa.eu/environment/security/rescue\_board/index_en.htm##117. *Bathing water quality and the access to public sanitation are the priority goals in Estonia*. **- #118.

2015, the water quality in Estonia was assessed at 84% of the national standards. This represents an increase of 13% over the previous year. The current level of water quality is 86% (2009: 85%). The water quality of the public water supply in Estonia is estimated to be 70% above the national minimum standards for drinking-water quality. **Recommendations for action by regional priority goals:- Water quality and access to public water supplies are the main priorities.#### **Priority goals- EU Water Framework Act 82- Estonian National Water Policy. **Annex 2. Additional information by regional prioritary goal 1: Water and sanitation* **Summary** *Tools for monitoring- The Health Protection Inspectorate is responsible for the development of public health policies and strategies.- The Ministry of Social Affairs is in charge of the implementation of these policies.

2003, the number of accidents involving radon and radium in drinking-water in Estonia was 1,000 per year, compared to 800 in 1990. The number of injuries caused by unintentional injuries was 2,500, compared with 4,700 during the same period last year. In addition, there was an increase in accidents due to excess body weight and obesity among young people (11–15 years old) compared to the previous year (16 years old).#### **Summary**- The Health Protection Inspectorate organizes the mapping of radiation in private households. The Radiation Protection Inspectorate performs monitoring.- The Regional priority goal 1: Water monitoring follows stricter requirements than average in the EU Region.- **Intersectoral collaboration**: The Ministry of Social Affairs and the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Communications are responsible for the development of a common database on water.

2003, the Ministry of Transport and Infrastructure was responsible for the implementation of the National Road Safety Programme (NRP).- The NRP has been implemented since 1998.- The road safety policy is based on the national road safety plan (National Road Safety Strategy) and the road safety regulations (Road Safety Regulations).- A number of road safety policies have been adopted in the past, but there are still many issues that need to be addressed.- There is a lack of coordination between the various ministries.#### **Tools for action*- The Ministry of Economic Affairs and Communications is in charge of the Road Safety Act.- It also has the following laws, policies and strategies.

2013, the Ministry of Social Affairs and Employment (Eesti Sotsiaalministeerium) published a report entitled “Indoor air pollution in Estonia” which highlighted the following issues:- Indoor smoke is the main cause of death in Estonia.- The number of people who die from smoke in the home is higher than in the rest of the European Union.- There is a high incidence of smoking in the public spaces, especially in urban areas.- Among young people, smoking is the most common cause of mortality.- Residential areas- The Government Commission on Road Accidents, Ministry of Justice, universities, NGOs and traffic schools.**Tools for management**- The government commission on road accidents has been set up.- Regional priority goal 3: Indoor air quality monitoring.

2008, the Ministry of Environment and Environment Protection (MEEP) launched a project to monitor the air quality in Tallinn and its surrounding areas.- The monitoring of PM10 and PM2.5 is carried out by the Estonian Environment Research Centre (EERC) and the Estonian Environmental Protection Agency (EEA).- Indoor air pollution is monitored by the National Air Quality Monitoring Network (NQAM).- Air quality monitoring is conducted in the following areas:- Tallinn, Pärnu, Narva, Valga, Viljandi, Jõgeva, Valgamaa, Harjumaa, Lääne-Virumaa, Saaremaa, Hiiumaa, Harju, Järvamaa, Tartu, Tartumaa, Võru and Tartumaa.- Other pollutants are monitored at the local level by the local authorities and municipalities.- Measurements are performed in accordance with the EU Directive on Air Quality (EU Directive 1999/45/EC).- The national air quality monitoring network consists of several stations.- There are 16 monitoring stations in the city of Tallinn.- A number of stations have been set up in other cities of Estonia.- Some of these stations are located in rural areas of the country.- These stations can be connected to the national monitoring network.- It is necessary to establish a coordinated monitoring system for the monitoring of outdoor air quality.- Each of the stations has its own monitoring system.- This monitoring system is based on the European Union directive on air quality, which was adopted by the European Parliament and the Council of Europe in 30 June 2% of the population lives in urban areas and 70% of residents live in rural communities.- For the purposes of this report, the following measures have been implemented:- Priority goal 3: Improving the quality of the air in the public spaces.- Main priority goal 4: Enhancing the protection of the health of people, animals, plants and foodstuffs from contamination.- Priorty goal 5: Promoting the use of environmentally friendly materials in the production of food.- Regional priority objectives:- To ensure that the environment is safe for humans, animals and vegetables.- Regulatory framework for

2013, the Health Protection Inspectorate (HPI) is responsible for monitoring the use of pesticides in foodstuffs. The HPI monitors the presence of pesticide residues in food and feed products, as well as the contamination of food products with pesticides. In addition, the HPI conducts regular inspections of all food products, including those containing pesticides, in order to ensure that they are safe for human consumption.The HPI also monitors chemical and biological contaminants in food products to ensure the safety of consumers and the environment.Regional priority goal 4: Food safety- **Tools for monitoring**The main laws, policies and strategies recently established in this field include:- Veterinary and Food Act: a separate Food Act; and- Plant Protection Act: an independent legislation.- **Intersectoral collaboration**There are two types of intersectoral cooperation.

2007, the number of employees who have been exposed to hazardous substances has increased by 15% compared to the same period of the previous year. The number of occupational diseases has also increased by about 30% compared with the same time period of 24 years ago. This is due to the fact that there are more than 100,000 new occupations in Estonia. Therefore, there is a need for a systematic approach to occupational health and safety. *Occupational health*- Occupational safety is assessed during risk assessment in industry.- **Policies*- Only one code is used for chemical safety.- Government decrees- Chemical Safety Act.- General Act on the Provision of Health Services.**Tools for action*- There is only one code for occupational safety.

2006, the number of accidents involving asbestos was 137.- The number of occupational accidents is 145.- Occupational health and safety regulations are not complied with.- There is a lack of information on the risks associated with the use of chemicals in the workplace.- Asbestos is a dangerous substance and therefore it is not safe to work with it.- It is not known how many people are exposed to the chemicals and how much noise they emit.- Riskasbestos- Checks are performed to determine whether the employees get the right instructions on how to deal with chemicals but also climate, noise, ventilation and social conditions etc. (Labour Inspectorate) *Monitoring*- Chemical safety is assessed during risk assessment in industry- **Tools for monitoring- Only 78% of the people surveyed knew that asbestas is dangerous or because of the fact that they have an Ambient Air Protection Act (environmental noise directive)

2003/87/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 29 September 2103 on the protection of children from noise in the public transport system, as amended by Directive 1999/44/EC (Noise Protection Directive) and Regulation (EC) No. 1024/2012 (Environmental Noise Directive). The following laws and policies have been adopted for the management of noise pollution in public transport systems:- Environmental Noise Act- Public Health Act- Ambient Air Protection Act (noise inside the building)- EU environmental noise directive

of the EHPRs are based on a comprehensive analysis of the environmental and health situation in Estonia. the implementation of the Integrated Disease Surveillance and Response (IDSR) Technical Guidelines, 2016-2020, which were developed by the WHO Regional Office for Africa (WHE) in collaboration with the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID). The purpose of the revision was to:- (a) Enhance the effectiveness of the existing surveillance systems and improve their performance- (b) Improve the quality of the information available to the Member States- (c) Increase the transparency of the system- (d) Promote the use of e-surveillance tools- (e) Reduce the risk of transmission of diseases- (f) Introduce new methods of monitoring and reporting- (g) Implement the IDSR technical guidelines.# ACKNOWLEDGMENTS- (A) ACCOUNTABILITY- (B) RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE REVISION OF THE IDSR TECHNICAL GUIDELINES

2018-2020, the WHO Regional Office for Africa (ROA) and the United States Agency for International Development (USAID/AFR) have worked together to develop a new version of the IDSR, which is based on the recommendations of the 1st and 2nd editions of the guidelines. The revised version was prepared in collaboration with the National Institutes of Health (NIH) of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and has been supported by the National Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (NCDCP).The revision process included:Dr Ibrahima Socé Fall, MD, MPH Technical Coordinator WHO/WHE/IHM, Brazzaville, CongoDr Zabulon Yahaya, MD

of a public health emergency preparedness and response plan (PHEPR). The PHEPR should include:- (a) the establishment of the Public Health Emergency Management Subcommittee (PHEMC);- (b) the identification and training of key members of the PHERRT;- (c) the development of a coordinating structure for public health emergencies or events/incidents at at least the national level as well as a similar coordination structure at the subnational level; and (d) the mapping of risks and the conduct of simulation exercises to test systems.# 5.Countries should establish the PHEOC and respond to public health events would be successful if there were:-

of the National Disaster Risk Management EOC, the PHEOC is responsible for the coordination of public health emergency preparedness and response activities at the national level. In addition, it is the responsibility of each State Party to establish and maintain a public health emergencies coordination centre (PHEOC) at the highest level of its national government, which will be in charge of coordinating and managing public health risks and emergency response activities. In order to achieve this objective, States Parties should: (a) develop and implement a national public health crisis management plan; (b) establish a national emergency management system; and (c) provide the necessary technical and financial resources for the operation and maintenance of the national disaster risk management system. The following elements are required for the establishment of a Public Health Emergency Preparedness and Response Centre:- (i) information and communication systems- (ii) telecommunication technology and infrastructure- (iii) trained human resources- (iv) coordination mechanisms- (v) monitoring and reporting mechanisms.Countries should establish the PHAOC, at least at national level, to act as a command and control centre that enhances coordination and oversees events in the community. The International Health Regulations (IHR 2005) require that countries develop, strengthen and maintain the capacity to respond promptly and effectively to public health hazards and public health emergences.

of the PHEOC is to coordinate the response to public health emergencies at the national and regional level. The IMS is responsible for the coordination of public health emergency responses in the context of the National Disaster Risk Management EOC (IDSR). It is also responsible to provide information and support to the government, the private sector and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) on the implementation of the IDSR. In addition, the IMS should be able to communicate effectively with the public health authorities and other relevant stakeholders in order to improve the response.Most importantly, the PHAOC should be functional at all levels of health system delivery (national, region/province and district). It should be positioned at the highest level where there is already an organ mandating the management of escalated events of national magnitude. It is highly recommended that the Pheoc is located in the Office of the Chief Medical Officer in some countries and in the office of the Director for Health in others.

5.2.1 Identify the roles and responsibilities of the public health emergency management committee (PHEMC) at the subnational level. The PHEMC should be responsible for coordinating and monitoring the implementation of the PHEOC, including:- (a) Developing and implementing national and regional emergency preparedness and response plans; (b) Identifying and identifying potential risks to public health; (c) Ensuring that public health emergencies are identified and managed in a timely and effective manner; and (d) Monitoring and reporting on their outcomes. **5.1.2 Identified the functions of the national/regional/district public health Emergency Management Committees (PHEMCS) and their responsibilities and functions.**5.3.1The PHAEMCS should be established at all levels.- (b), (c), (d), (e), (f), (g), (h), (i), (j), (k), (l), (m), (n), (o), (p), (q), (r), (s), (t) and (s)# 4.1 Establish a national PHEOMC.

, the PHEOC is responsible for coordinating the response to an outbreak of an infectious disease or other public health event at the national level. It is the responsibility of the NPHA and the IHR to ensure that all stakeholders are aware of the risks associated with the outbreak and that they take appropriate measures to prevent the spread of the disease. In addition, it is the duty of the National Public Health Authority (NPHA) and the District Health Management Team (DHT) to ensure the effective implementation of the recommended response activities.# 6.1 When an epidemic threshold is reached, an effective coordination of response activities is also critical. Under the International Health Regulations (IHR, 2005).

6.2.1 The IHR NFP will coordinate the response efforts with the neighbouring districts (and provinces or regions where applicable) to ensure that there is coordination of response efforts. They will then inform the Minister of Health or the competent sector ministry about the outbreak. If there is no confirmation of the laboratory diagnosis, there may be a declaration of an outbreak by the minister of health or the concerned sector ministry. **6.3.1 Initiate the preparation of the public health emergency rapid response team (PHERRT) for immediate action.- (a) Request the release of outbreak or event response funds. If they are already established cross-border surveillance and response framework with a neighboring district, then they will communicate with them as well as their roles and responsibilities.**6.4.1The Public Health Emergency Rapid Response Teams (PHerrt) would have already been identified during preparedness activities. - (i) identify and implement appropriate public health response activities that would contain the confirmed outbreak or public health event; (ii) establish a coordinated response plan to address the specific causes of the outbreak, including:- (a) prevention and control of the disease;- (b) improving access to clean water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH);- (c) preventing and controlling the spread of disease.- (d) identifying and implementing measures to reduce the risk of unnecessary deaths or disabilities in the short term.Refer to Section 11.0- (j) Ensure investigation results and data analysis interpretation provided by Public Health Emergency Rapid Response Team (PHERRT).

6.3.1 (a) Ensure that hospitals and other health facilities are equipped with the necessary equipment, equipment, and personnel to deal with cases of highly infectious diseases; (b) ensure that all patients are treated in accordance with IPC guidelines; (c) provide appropriate sanitary and hygiene standards for hospitals; and (d) ensure adequate disposal of contaminated food and waste; (e) ensure safe and dignified burial and handling of dead bodies; and adequate logistics and supplies.- (j) improve clinical practices- (l) improve exposure to contagious or environmental hazards; (k) improve sanitization and decontamination practices.

of risk communication in the context of public health emergencies is to communicate effectively and efficiently about the outbreak and its consequences. Risk communication is an integral part of any public health intervention, as well as of all other public health interventions. In addition, it is important to ensure that risk communication is carried out in a timely and effective manner, so that people who are at risk are able to take informed decisions to mitigate the effects of the threat (hazard) such as a disease outbreak, preventable death and disease with the least possible disruption to economies and society.# 7.1 The current 21st century has been marked by an exponential growth of travel, trade, migration, and license CC BY-NC-SA 3'

of risk communication in the context of Integrated Disease Surveillance and Response (IDSR) is to provide decision-makers with the knowledge they need to make informed decisions for protective action. It also provides summary information especially regarding outbreak response, so that they can review how resources were applied to contain the event. Effective risk communication should be included in all IDSR core functions and activities, particularly detection, sample collection, reporting, analysis and interpretation, feedback, response and preparedness. When effective risk communication is properly conducted, it can improve decision-making and the adoption of recommended behaviours by communities and thus contribute to the prevention, control and response to priority diseases and other public health events with the least possible disruption to economies and society. **7.1.1 Risk communication benefits# 7.2.1 The risk communication strategy is well planned and integrated into IDSR.

s of risk communication include:- Communicating information and advice to people who are at risk of being infected with a disease, such as doctors, nurses, health care workers, etc.- Identifying and communicating with people who have been exposed to the disease, including family members, friends and neighbors, and providing guidance on how to protect themselves and others from the spread of the disease. **7.1.1 Target audiences for risk communication**- Health-care providers and first responders- Hospitals and health-care facilities- Schools and workplaces- Surveillance officers- Maternal and child health organizations, partners, and community stakeholders.**7.2.1 Community engagement and its relevance to public health emergency response.**

of the outbreak communication strategy is to ensure that the public is aware of the risks associated with an outbreak, and that they are prepared to take action if they become aware of them. of anthrax in Moshi Rural District was reported to the Ministry of Health and Social Welfare (MOHSW) in 2005. The outbreak occurred in the village of Marangu, Moshi DC, Kilimanjaro Region, Kenya. 2000-2010, the onchocerciasis control programme in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) was funded by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and the World Health Organization (WHO). The objectives of the project were: to develop a framework for evaluating the sustainability of CDTI projects in the DRC; to assess the impact of these projects on the health of the population; to evaluate the effectiveness of the programs; to identify the areas where there is a need for improvements; to establish priorities.In response to this section we introduce you to important information, which will help you understand the following:-'To develop an external evaluation framework, since APOC funding became available to the member countries in 1999;# I. to develop a framework for evaluating the sustainability of projects in their fifth year of APOC funding. This framework will be used to evaluate the project's performance in terms of:-'Sustainability: The ability of a project to continue functioning effectively after APOC support comes to an end, provided both the necessary political decisions, administrative measures and resources (financial, human, material) are in place, and can reasonably be expected to continue to be so for the foreseeable future.'. To develop a short manual using this framework.-'To developaframework with realistic and measurable indicators of sustainbility.

s of sustainability are:- Efficiency: Projects are more likely to be sustainable if they are run cost-effectively, and if they have sufficient resources (human' material, financial) to support what they are trying to do. \t*tli"h Projects that are not sustainable are less likely to succeed.- Sustainability: The project is less sustained if it is run in the absence of additional material reward.- Efficiency: The projects are less sustainably if they don't have adequate resources.## 1.L.1 Aspects of sustainabilityWe have to judge that projects will be more sustainable when the following aspects are present.- Integration: The programs are more sustainables if they become part of the routine running of the health services.- <sup>a</sup> Community ownership- Attitude of the stalJ,.

the second edition of the IDSR guidelines in 2015, the WHO Secretariat will continue to focus on the implementation of the IHR (2005) in the African Region, with the aim of improving public health surveillance and response to public health threats. The goal of the third edition is to provide a comprehensive framework for developing and implementing the International Health Regulations (IHR) for the Africa Region, which will serve as a guideline for the development of national strategies for disaster risk management (DRM) across the region. *Many public health events and emergencies could be prevented, detected and mitigated, or their associated risk factors could be reduced. *I am pleased to unveil the *IDSR technical guidelines, which were first published in 1998, and have since been revised several times.

- (a) health workers at all levels (including public health officers, clinicians, laboratory personnel and public health workers)- (b) local and regional health officials- (c) national and regional surveillance agencies- (d) local health authorities- (e) health professionals- (f) public health experts- (g) other public health specialists- (h) health and social workers- (i) medical staff- (j) hospitals and other health care facilities- (k) community health teams- (l) government agencies and non-governmental organizationsThese guidelines recommend thresholds for action on priority diseases, public health events and conditions, or their associated risk factors could be prevented, or its effects mitigated. All Member States are urged to implement these IDSR guidelines as a stand-alone reference.

the implementation of the Integrated Disease Surveillance and Response (IDSR) guidelines in Africa, including:- (a) a general reference for surveillance activities at all levels; (b) a set of standard definitions for threshold levels that initiate action for responding to specific diseases; (c) a resource for improving early detection and response to epidemic-prone diseases.The third edition of the IDSR technical guidelines was prepared by the WHO Regional Office for Health Emergencies (WHE) Programme with the active involvement of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID).Dr Matshidiso Moeti WHO Regional Director for Africa.

2nd edition of the IHR, 2005, was published in 1998 and was revised in 3rd edition (2014) in order to include:- a) Recognize the importance of the role of community health surveillance in preventing and treating diseases.- b) Introduce new concepts and methods for identifying diseases and their prevention.- c) Increase the number of clinical trials conducted in Africa.- d) Improve the quality of information available to the public.- e) Dr Ibrahima Socé Yoti, MD, MPH WHO/WHE, Brazzaville, Congo.- f) Update the guidelines with contemporary information, taking into account new developments such as: emerging and re-emerging priority diseases, conditions and events.- g) Incorporate recent recommendations from expert panels that are underpinned by the EVD outbreak in West Africa, polio eradication and other humanitarian crises.

100% of reporting sites have submitted their surveillance reports within the specified period of time;** 20% have not submitted such reports, and 30% do not have any reports at all. **8.3.1.1 Completion of Surveillance Reporting:* (a) The completeness of the reporting site can be measured by:- (i) the number of cases reported- (ii) the quantity of data collected- (iii) the quality of the information provided- (iv) the time required- (b) the deadlines given for each level.### *8.4.2.1 Completeness of surveillances reporting:- measure how many monthly reports are given for every level.

8.3.1.1 Identify problems and take action* If there is a problem with the quality of surveillance data, it should be reported to the health facility responsible for the facility. For example, if there is an outbreak of measles in a facility, the reporting unit at the local level should provide information about the number of cases that have been detected. If there are more than 100 cases, they should report them to the district. If the number is less than 50, then the reports should be sent to the national level.- (ii) What is the implication of missing data, and what problems can be solved?- (iii) How can this problem be resolved?* If not, which variables are not collected routinely, and if the report is not on time, or if the monitoring information shows that the report has not been provided, or any other rapporting unit has not provided a report, or does not have a reliable supply of forms or other supply method such as text messaging or radiophone, then it should include also necessary data for improving the situation.

Another purpose is to raise awareness about certain diseases and any achievements made by disease-control and prevention projects in the area.

reports should include:- (i) a summary of the results of the surveillance system; (ii) a report of the progress made in the implementation of the IDSR; (iii) an overview of the outcomes of the project; (iv) an evaluation of the performance of the health worker; (v) an assessment of the effectiveness of the program; (vi) an explanation of the reasons for the success of the programme; (vii) an analysis of the impact of the plan on the district's health care system; and (viii)a report of cases of diarrhoea with dehydration in children aged less than 5 years.###(ii) Prepare a single sheet with data reported for a given period or target population, and compare it with the same period last year; use summary sheets to support requests made to higher levels for additional funds, supplies and resources. ###(b) Developing district newsletters**Examples of articles that could be carried in a district Newsletter

evaluation of the surveillance system should include:- (a) identification of objectives; (b) definition of indicators; (c) determination of how the system is implemented; (d) assessment of the effectiveness of the system; and (e) analysis of the results of the evaluation. **8.6.1 Identifying evaluation indicators for each evaluation objective, including the scope of evaluation, target group, data sources, and methodologies used to evaluate the system.These indicators should:- ## ##8.5.1 Indicators should be clearly defined and consistent with the overall outcomes of the program. #### ##8.4.2.1.1## #8.3.1.## ## 8.7.1Indicators should be identified. If there is already an IDSR implementation plan, then this should include the following steps:- (####) show the extent to which desired outputs and outcome are achieved.- (B) provide explanations for achievements, disparities and failures- (C) provide explications for failures.

evaluation should be carried out by the provincial/regional health offices, which are responsible for monitoring and reporting to the national level. *8.6.5.1 To ensure that the surveillance data received from all health facilities in the catchment area are accurate, accurate and up-to-date, and that the results of the evaluation are consistent with the results obtained at the local level, the regional/provincial health departments should monitor the performance of the health facilities at their local level and provide feedback to the district health office on the progress made.- (a) To ensure objectiveness and transparency during the examination process, a blend of self-internal and external evaluations should be conducted periodically.

8.6.5.1 Summary data for the year are as follows:- (a) The number of cases and deaths reported to the district over the previous year- (b) The amount of time spent on surveillance and response activities- (c) The level of compliance with health standards- (d) The quality of health services provided- (e) The effectiveness of the health care system- (f) The impact of health care services on the population- (g) The performance of health facilities- (h) The efficiency of health service delivery- (i) As a result## **Use a monitoring chart, such as the one on the next page, to monitor performance of indicators at your level. Share these results with staff in your catchment level, and acknowledge successes and help maintain positive progress.

8.6.5 Identify the areas of improvement that were identified during the evaluation, including:- (a) Improvements in the quality of health care;- (b) Increases in the number of patients treated for COVID-19; and (c) Ameliorations in the level of surveillance.- (d) Recommendations for improving the health facility's response to COVID- 19.- **8.5.6 Identifies the areas where improvements have been made in the health care system.- ####### (g) Were any problems occurred, and the district did not meet an expected target, or reached a desired level of performance with any health staff requests or suggestions?- (h) Did any actions be taken to address health staff requirements or suggested measures about services or Surveillance?** (f) Was there any problems, and what were the reasons for those problems?-

2005, the International Health Regulations (IHR) were adopted by the General Assembly of the United Nations (UN) in 1948. The IHR has been implemented in more than 100 countries worldwide, and the implementation of e-tools in the health sector has been accelerated by the adoption of the World Health Organization (WHO) Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNCRPD) and the International Convention on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (ICESCR), which were signed by the United States of America, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, the European Union, the Russian Federation, China, India, Japan, South Africa and the United Arab Emirates.The main objectives of eIDSR are as follows:- 5. Electronic IDSR (eIDSR) is the application of electronic tools to principles of IDSR to facilitate prevention, prediction, detection, reporting and response. It is based on:- a) standardized interoperable and interconnected information systems administered within the national context;- b) rapid collection, analysis, and reporting of disease/events data in real time for appropriate public health action.

eIDSR is an electronic health information system (eHSI) that provides access to information on diseases, conditions, and other health-related data. The eHealth system is used to monitor the health of individuals, families, and communities, and to provide information about diseases and conditions that are identified by the health facility's outpatient or inpatient register (IPD). The eHSI is also used to track the health status of patients and their caregivers. In 2013, the World Health Organization (WHO) adopted a resolution on eHealth:- (a) e-health, which means transmission of health information over the traditional classroom;- (b) tele-health;- e-learning;- m-health.There are two main types of eHealth platforms.In both HMIS and e IDSR, there is an active and timely means of collecting data on health facilities OPD or IPD registers, and conditions which are extracted from either the OPD register or the IPD registry. The most widely used electronic platform of HMIS is DHIS2. In the Seventy-first World Health Assembly, the Member States echoed the sentiment of the e-Health platform, there are two primary means of source data derived from the HMIS or e-IDSR registers.

digital health strategies, including the implementation of eHealth, is a key element in achieving the IHR (2005) objectives. In addition, digital health solutions should support and enhance existing health service delivery models, supporting and investing in the digital health enabling environment (including policy, standards, capacity, interoperability, privacy and security, and more), and transitioning to sustainability and government ownership. Digital health solutions, as defined by the Broadband Commission for Sustainable Development, are an umbrella term that encompasses all concepts and activities at the intersection of health and information and communication technologies (ICTs) to capture, store, manage and transmit information on patient health or health facility activities. This leads to delays in generating and sharing country and regional profiles of priority diseases, conditions and events.Limitations of the current approaches to IDSR in health and health-related fields.Digital health, which is sometimes called eIDSR, provides cost-effective and secure use of ICTs.

eIDSR can be used to:- (i) Monitor outbreaks of diseases that have been identified as priority diseases in a specific country or region.- (ii) Identifies and reports on diseases which have already been reported in other countries or regions.** (iii) Provides information on the status of disease control and prevention, including the number of infected persons, the type of disease, the frequency and severity of the disease, and the location of the outbreak.- **(iv) Identify and report diseases with high priority## **(eIDSR provides an opportunity for reporting to higher level offices at regular intervals and providing reports from various sources and data storage and transport can be difficult, and there is a risk of data damage and loss.**(v)*(f)**(g)**

eIDSR should be designed and implemented in accordance with the following principles:- (a) **Standardization:** Each country should have its own standards and procedures for the implementation of eID SR, which should be consistent with those of other countries. (b) **Near real-time approach:** Every effort should be made to ensure that the data is collected and used in a timely and efficient manner. (c) **Multisectoral collaboration:** In order to achieve this goal, there should be a coordinated approach between all stakeholders in the health system. (d) **Interoperability:** The following are key principles that should be taken into account in the design and implementation process of eIdSR.- (e) **Infrastructure:** As much as practicable, eIDSL should be built on existing infrastructure and systems, such as paper-based IDSR, HMIS, DHIS2, etc. This allows easy adaptability by implementers, and promotes smooth transitions.

eIDSR should be designed and implemented in accordance with the following principles:- (i) **Easy to use:** The system should be easy to use for all stakeholders. (ii) **Fast and efficient:** Easily accessible information should be available in a timely manner. (iii) **Reliable:** Information should be accurate, up-to-date and accessible to all. (iv) **Structured:** It should be possible to integrate data from different sources into one system. (v) **Development:**The most important considerations for developing and implementing an eidsr system are shown below. **(g) **Intelligent:** In order to achieve this objective, it is necessary to ensure that the system is capable of responding to the needs of the country. (h) **Integrated:** This means that it can be used by all relevant actors in the health care system.- (j) **Collaborative:** There is a need for collaboration between all relevant parties involved in the development and implementation of the system.** (k) **Agile:** A system that can be integrated into the existing system should have the following characteristics:** (l) **Security:** Implementation should be carried out within the framework of the national laws, regulations, and policies of the respective country. **9.6.1 EIDSR must be able to communicate effectively with other eIDsr systems. (m) **Consistent:* The system must be compatible with existing standards and procedures. ** (n) **Comprehensive:** An eID SR system should include the following components:## (o) **Transparent:** Everything should be clearly identified and documented. (q) **Confidential:** Data should be kept confidential. (p) **Unique:** All data should be accessible. (s) **Accessible:** Access to information should not be restricted to specific areas of the health system, such as hospitals, hospital facilities, hospitals and clinical practices.** **(f) **Personalized:** Healthcare providers should be aware of the risks associated with

eIDSR, the following steps should be taken: (i) Identify the needs of the country in terms of ICT capabilities and infrastructure; (ii) Determine the requirements for the implementation of electronic disease surveillance; (iii) Establish a technical working group (TWG) that will be responsible for developing and implementing the system. The TWG should be composed of representatives of all relevant stakeholders in the country, including health care providers, public health agencies, and other relevant sectors. (iv) Develop and implement an e-IDSR functionality## **(ii) EIDSR needs to be coordinated with the national telecommunications industry; telephone companies; internet companies; and partners.

eSurveillance assessment tool can be used to assess the capabilities and resources of a country's eIDSR system. This tool can also be used as a resource tool to evaluate the coverage of the network. For example, if a country has a limited number of providers, it may be necessary to consider the following factors:- (i) Network coverage; (ii) Providers; (iii) Connectivity; (iv) Power supply; (v) Data storage; (vi) Storage capacity; (vii) Capacity; (ix) Cost; (xii) Availability of equipment; (xvi) Cost of subscription; (xsvi) cost of text messaging; cost of telephone calls; costs of data storage; costs for data storage and data processing; cost for data processing and data analysis; cost/effectiveness; cost-efficiency; cost per user; costs per user- (viii) Infrastructure- The following factors should be taken into consideration when assessing the eIdSR system in a given country.- (II) Network capability- Internet and mobile: number of operators; internet speed; internet coverage in all areas of the country; national level connectivity.

9.6.1 Implementation of eIDSR** should be carried out in accordance with the following criteria:- (i) Eligibility of the system for implementation- (ii) Requirements for data collection and storage- (iii) Availability of data-based services- (iv) Compliance with applicable laws and regulations- (v) Access to data should be controlled- (vi) Data security and user-agreement policies should be established- (vii) The system should be accessible to the public- and private sectors-(iii) ##### **(b) The following considerations are deemed important for the implementation of e IDSR**:-(iii) Incorporate routine monitoring and regular evaluations, including initial baseline assessments, prior to implementation.

eIDSR should be implemented within the framework of the existing eHealth system. (iv) There should be adequate resources to support operational infrastructure, such as mobile devices and computers, and associated operational costs. These components should be anchored within national eHealth policy and strategy. It is important to note that there should be advocacy for domestic financial resource allocation as well as innovative financial solutions, including leveraging resources from the private sector. **(f) Interoperability** The implementation of e-IDSR in the public health sector should be based on:- (i)There should be sufficient resources for continuing capacity building, training, re-training, etc.- (ii) Resources for continued data quality assessment/Assurance- (iii) Resource allocation for e-tools should be established.

A clear solution is driven by the conviction that everyone should be able to realize the right to health. But today, at least half of the world's people should have access to health services.

-care interventions are the first step towards achieving the Sustainable Development Goals of the United Nations (SDGs) and the World Health Organization (WHO) through the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Health. This guideline is the first consolidated guideline of the WHO on self-care, and it will be the first guideline to be published by the WHO in the context of the SDGs.

The people-centred approach to health should be complemented with a self- care model through which people can be empowered to prevent, test for and treat disease themselves.

2015, the World Health Organization (WHO) released the Guideline for the Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation (GRADE). This guideline was developed in collaboration between the WHO, the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the International Organization for Migration (IOM). -care is the ability of individuals, families and communities to promote health, prevent disease, maintain health, and cope with illness and disability with or without the support of a healthcare provider. The scope of self-care as described in this definition includes health promotion; disease prevention and control; providing care to dependent persons; seeking hospital/specialist/primary care if necessary; and rehabilitation, including palliative care. It is urgent to find innovative strategies that go beyond the conventional health sector response, such as task sharing and task shifting.#### FIGURE 1: SELF-CARE IN THE CONTEXT OF HEALTH SYSTEMS

-care interventions have the potential to contribute to:- improved health, human rights and social outcomes;- reduced coverage and access;- increased quality of health and human rights;- enhanced health and well-being of individuals, families and communities;- better access to health services;- more equitable and efficient use of health-care resources and services. The guidance also provides:- evidence-based recommendations on key public health self-care intervention strategies that will promote active participation in their health and an exciting way forward, including:- increased coverage And equity;- lowered health disparities And increased quality Of Health Services.

-based recommendations on key public health self-care interventions, including for advancing sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR), with a focus on vulnerable populations and settings with limited capacity and resources in the health system. The conceptual framework provides a starting point for tackling and increasing safe and equitable access to, uptake and use of, and service-delivery of Self-Care interventions across the whole life course, taking into account their individual circumstances, needs and desires, as well as the environment within which they live. This guideline also provides:#### CONCEPTUAL FRAMEWORK FOR SELF-CARE INTERVENTIONS- evidence-based statements on key programmatic, operational and use issues that need to be addressed.

-care interventions to advance health and well-being: a conceptual framework to inform normative guidance. BMJ. 2019;365:l688. doi:10.1136/bmj.l678. This new guideline is expected to support persons affected by the recommendations: those who are taking care of themselves and who are unable to make decisions around sexuality and reproduction. This is true for many people who are not in a position to exercise autonomy over their bodies and for vulnerable persons.#### SCOPE OF SELF-CARE INTERVENTIONS TO ADVANCE HEALTH AND WELFARE: A CONCEPTUAL FRAMEWORK TO INFORM NORMATIVE GUIDANCE.

-care interventions in low-resource settings can be implemented in a variety of ways, including: 1. By providing access to self-care services for people who are vulnerable or marginalized; 2. By creating a safe and supportive environment for the implementation of these interventions; 3. By identifying the needs of vulnerable and marginalized populations; 4. By ensuring that they have access to adequate health care services; 5. By promoting the inclusion of women in the health-care system; 6. By facilitating the participation of women and their families in the development of the guideline; 7. By developing an appropriate framework for the guidance.#### AN ENABLING ENVIRONMENT FOR SELF-CARE INTERVENTIONS, IF IT IS SITUATED IN A SAFE AND SUPPORTIVE ENVIronment is essential to facilitate access to and uptake of products and interventions that can improve their health and well-being (Figure 3). The WHO Department of Reproductive Health and Research led the SG to develop this consolidated guideline.

2019, the GDG and the ERG were invited to participate in the drafting of the guideline. The SG identified the following topic areas where new recommendations needed to be developed: self-administration of injectable contraception; over-the-counter (OTC) provision of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs); use of home-based ovulation predictor kits (HPVSS) for cervical cancer screening; self-collection of samples (SCS) for sexually transmitted infections (STIs).The SG oversaw the process of screening the existing WHO guidance documents and identifying the priority questions in PICO (population, intervention, comparator, outcome) format; and recruiting the Guideline methodologist and members of the systematic review teams, the SG. The GDG was asked to review the draft guideline to provide technical feedback, identify factual errors, comment on the clarity of the language, and provide input on considerations related to the implementation of thedocument. 2019, the GDG adopted the GRADE approach to developing recommendations for self-care interventions in humanitarian settings. The goal of this guideline is to provide a comprehensive overview of existing recommendations and their impacts on human rights. In addition, it aims to establish a framework for the development of new recommendations that will support the implementation of SRHR interventions by health-care providers. This framework will be used as a starting point for future research in the field of self care interventions, and will serve as a guideline for the future.In accordance with the WHO guideline development process, specific attention was given to (i) the quality and certainty of the available evidence and (ii) the effectiveness, safety and delivery of the recommendations.

of the guideline is to provide a framework for the implementation and evaluation of self-care interventions in health-care systems. The guideline will be used as a tool for evaluating the effectiveness, safety, efficacy, and delivery of SRHR interventions. In addition, the GDG will provide guidance on how to implement the recommendations of this guideline. The GDG’s objectives are to: 1. Improve the quality of health care services 2. Increase the accessibility to SRHR services 3. Promote the use of digital health and digital therapeutics 4.Effective implementation of these recommendations and good practice statements will require new opportunities to generate real-world evidence in real time. However, it demands that the new recommendations be implemented in real-time. During the development process and in-person GDG meeting, the following topics will be discussed:#### IMPLEMENTATION, APPLICABILITY, AND MONITORING AND EVALUATION OF THESE RECOMMENDATIONS AND GOOD PRACTICE STATEMENT

the current version of the SRHR guideline, there are a number of new and existing recommendations on self-care interventions for SRHR that are likely to be included in future versions of the guideline. These include: (1) Improving antenatal, delivery, postpartum and newborn care; (2) Providing high-quality services for family planning, including infertility services; (3) Eliminating unsafe abortion; and (4) Combating sexually transmitted infections, including cervical cancer and other gynaecological morbidities.This guideline aims to develop further guidance on SRHR and other health areas that would be likely to promote equity, be feasible to implement, and contribute to improvements in Self-care.The concept for this guideline is a "living guideline". In a fast-moving field, this approach allows for continuous review of new evidence and an update of existing guidelines.

-care interventions are designed to improve health and well-being of individuals, families and communities. To achieve these goals, it is necessary to create an enabling environment for the implementation of self-care initiatives. In order to achieve these objectives, the following principles should be taken into account: 1. Access to and use of health services must be facilitated by a safe and supportive environment. 2. The quality of the environment must be appropriate to the needs of the individual. 3. Health systems must be accessible. 4.####2.22 WHO CONSOLIDATED GUIDELINES ON SELF-CARE INTERVENTIONS FOR HEALTH SYSTEM

-care interventions are designed to support individuals' health and well-being, and to improve their quality of life. The goal of the guideline is to provide a framework for the implementation of self-care initiatives in the health system. This framework is based on the WHO HEALTH SYSTEM FRAMEWORK *(2)*, which was published in 2007 by the World Health Organization (WHO). In this framework, the following principles are identified: *[\t1\t]1.Self-care intervention should not be used as a substitute for medical care or other health care services. *[(1)\t]*These principles have been formulated by the WHO Health System Framework *(1)*

2.2.1. Self-care Interventions must be designed to draw systematic attention to key areas of potential concern in order to inform actions that might militate against these negative impacts and, instead, ensure supportive and responsive health system and broader enabling environment.

health workers are responsible for the provision of health care and treatment services to the individuals in their communities. In order to achieve universal health coverage, it is necessary to improve the quality of health services provided by health professionals and community health workers at the primary health care level. To do so, the health workforce must be trained and trained in the following areas: *[\t(3\t)](page-52-1)*. 2.2.1 Self-care interventions for sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) should be conducted in an inclusive and non-stigmatizing manner, and should be based on a pre-service training pathway of 12–48 months.Service provision or delivery is a direct function of the inputs into the health system, such as the healthworkforce, procurement/supplies, and financing: increased inputs should lead to improved service delivery and enhanced access to services.

healthcare providers and managers of healthcare facilities need to acknowledge that people have always and will continue to practice self-care that is not initiated by the health system. For example, mobile phones, tablets and other information and communications technologies (ICTs) may be useful in overcoming language barriers and ensuring that potential users can make informed decisions about their personal health and well-being as they rely on it. Healthcare information and services must be available and accessible at the time and place they are needed, and they must also be acceptable and of high quality.

-administration of DMPA-SC has been recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) as an alternative to injectable contraception for women under 18 years of age who have not had access to a provider-administered method of contraception. The new recommendation is based on the findings of a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study conducted in 2020. The results indicate that DMPA can be used as an optional contraceptive for women who are not able to receive a pre-filled needle or other contraceptives, thereby removing barriers, such as the need to return to a healthcare facility every three months for a repeat injection.

-based ovulation predictor kits (OPKs) have been used for more than 20 years, and the use of OPKs has increased significantly since 1998. The use of home-based OPK in fertility management has been discussed extensively in international journals, including the European Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology (EJOG), the American Journal of Urology (AOJ), the International Journal of Sexual Medicine (IJSM), the Journal of Clinical and Experimental Medicine (JCM) and the European Medical Journal (EMEJ). The SG determined that the home- based OPK's do not directly indicate a peak fertility day, and multiple pregnancy attempts may still be needed within the appropriate timeframe.

1992 to 2013, there were 14 studies in which OPKs were used as an outcome of fertility treatment or investigation. The study was published in the Journal of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) on 15 June 1892. The PICOs used in the reviewed studies could be both urine-based kits and any modality (stick, monitor, digital, electronic slip that connects to a phone, etc.).
